newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: FEATURE - Malaysia multimedia zone draws multi views.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Malaysia multimedia zone draws multi views.

text.p: Malaysia's Multimedia Super Corridor (MSC) project is being conceived with input from a phalanx of foreign computer companies, including networking firm Sun Microsystems Inc and software giant Microsoft Corp.
But there could be trouble in the proposed "multimedia utopia". What else but a futuristic testbed for high-technology, high-speed communications products could bring such rival companies together?

The two U.S.-based companies are members of the MSC International Advisory Panel, a collection of over 30 top computer firms, mostly cobbled together personally by Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.
RIVALS MAY SPAR IN MALAYSIAN CORRIDOR
Already arch-rivals on their home turf, there's been strong hints the jostling could carry on overseas in Malaysia.

On a Malaysian visit in June to launch a facility that promotes training in its own Java programming language, Sun Microsystems' chief executive Scott McNealy described Microsoft's Windows operating system as dead and said the MSC would be a part of the rivalry.
"IBM won the first wave, Hewlett-Packard the second, Intel and Microsoft the third, and we're going to lead the charge ... against the dark side," McNealy said.
"We are going to lead the rebel forces and I think the MSC is a very, very important component of the rebel forces," he added.

Sun and Microsoft, which have both lined up support from other high-technology firms, not only battle on computer systems, but also on two versions of newly-launched stripped down, cheaper personal computers (PCs).
The Microsoft-Intel alliance is offering the NetPC, a diskless, sealable PC designed around Intel microprocessors, which can run most Microsoft software, and is aimed at corporate networks.
Sun Microsystems, Oracle Corp and others are promoting NCs or Network Computers, which are similar to NetPCs, but have only basic Internet and corporate network access functions.
Both sides have sniped at each other about the expected popularity of the new PCs which cost around $1,000, with Microsoft boss Bill Gates saying that NC stands for "non-compatible".
MALAYSIANS HOLD ABOVE THE FRAY
So far, Malaysian government officials and high-technology industry players are nonchalant about the Sun-Microsoft infighting.
"It takes an Asian to bring them together," chuckled Tengku Azzman Shariffadeen, chief executive of MIMOS Bhd, a key government player in the MSC project.
Asked recently if Malaysia was concerned about conflicting advice on the MSC from diametrically opposed philosophies, Tengku Azzman said: "We just want to know what are their best ideas."
He added that at an early meeting of the panel, most of the ideas focused on broad strategies, not operating systems.

Dan Khoo, head of The Association of Computer Industry Malaysia, whose 220 members include foreign and local high-tech firms, said: "It's not as if we are totally dependent on everybody. It's not like we cannot think for ourselves."
HIGH-TECH ZONE DEPENDENT ON FOREIGN FIRMS
However, the success of the MSC is heavily dependent on the enthusiasm of foreign companies to participate in the project and guide it.

The 15-by-50 kilometre (9-by-30 mile) corridor will extend south from Malaysia's capital of Kuala Lumpur to its new international airport and include an "intelligent" city Cyberjaya and a new "wired" federal capital, Putrajaya.
About 40 firms, mostly foreign, have signed up to participate in the zone.
Including divergent viewpoints of the information technology future could help Malaysia hedge its bets on the project's success, some industry executives say.

"The way the industry moves, you can never tell whose view of the world is right at any time," said Ramesh Gopal, business development manager at U.S. networking firm Cisco Systems Inc "People are wary of single-views of the world."
